member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PooledObjects.ObjectPool`1
member.summary:
Generic implementation of object pooling pattern with predefined pool size limit. The main purpose is that limited number of frequently used objects can be kept in the pool for further recycling.
Notes: 1) it is not the goal to keep all returned objects. Pool is not meant for storage. If there is no space in the pool, extra returned objects will be dropped.
2) it is implied that if object was obtained from a pool, the caller will return it back in a relatively short time. Keeping checked out objects for long durations is ok, but reduces usefulness of pooling. Just new up your own.
Not returning objects to the pool in not detrimental to the pool's work, but is a bad practice. Rationale: If there is no intent for reusing the object, do not use pool - just use "new".

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PooledObjects.ObjectPool`1.Factory
member.remarks: Not using System.Func{T} because this file is linked into the (debugger) Formatter, which does not have that type (since it compiles against .NET 2.0).

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PooledObjects.ObjectPool`1.Allocate
member.summary: Produces an instance.
member.remarks: Search strategy is a simple linear probing which is chosen for it cache-friendliness. Note that Free will try to store recycled objects close to the start thus statistically reducing how far we will typically search.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PooledObjects.ObjectPool`1.Free(`0)
member.summary: Returns objects to the pool.
member.remarks: Search strategy is a simple linear probing which is chosen for it cache-friendliness. Note that Free will try to store recycled objects close to the start thus statistically reducing how far we will typically search in Allocate.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PooledObjects.ObjectPool`1.ForgetTrackedObject(`0,`0)
member.summary:
Removes an object from leak tracking.
This is called when an object is returned to the pool. It may also be explicitly called if an object allocated from the pool is intentionally not being returned to the pool. This can be of use with pooled arrays if the consumer wants to return a larger array to the pool than was originally allocated.

member.summary: If someone need to create a private pool

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Debugging.CustomDebugInfoKind
member.summary: The kinds of custom debug info that we know how to interpret. The values correspond to possible values of the "kind" byte in the record header.

member.summary: C# only. Encodes the sizes of using groups that are applicable to the method. The actual import strings are stored separately trhu ISymUnmanagedWriter.UsingNamespace.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Debugging.CustomDebugInfoKind.ForwardMethodInfo
member.summary: C# only. Indicates that per-method debug information (import strings) is stored on another method, whose token is specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Debugging.CustomDebugInfoKind.ForwardModuleInfo
member.summary: C# only. Indicates that per-module debug information (assembly reference aliases) is stored on another method, whose token is specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Debugging.CustomDebugInfoKind.StateMachineHoistedLocalScopes

member.summary: C# and VB. The name of the state machine type. Emitted for async and iterator kick-off methods.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Debugging.CustomDebugInfoKind.DynamicLocals

member.summary: For each namespace declaration enclosing a method (innermost-to-outermost), there is a count of the number of imports in that declaration.
member.remarks: There's always at least one entry (for the global namespace). Exposed for .

member.summary: This indicates that further information can be obtained by looking at the custom debug info of another method (specified by token).
member.remarks: Appears when multiple method would otherwise have identical using records (see ). Exposed for .

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Debugging.CustomDebugInfoReader.DecodeForwardToModuleRecord(System.Collections.Immutable.ImmutableArray{System.Byte})
member.summary: This indicates that further information can be obtained by looking at the custom debug info of another method (specified by token).
member.remarks: Appears when there are extern aliases and edit-and-continue is disabled. Exposed for .

member.summary: Does for locals what System.Runtime.CompilerServices.DynamicAttribute does for parameters, return types, and fields. In particular, indicates which occurrences of in the signature are really dynamic.
member.remarks: Appears when there are dynamic locals. Exposed for .
member.exception: Bad data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Debugging.CustomDebugInfoReader.TryParseCSharpImportString(System.String,System.String@,System.String@,System.String@,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Debugging.ImportTargetKind@)
member.summary: Parse a string representing a C# using (or extern alias) directive.
member.remarks: For C#: "USystem" -> <namespace name="System" /> "AS USystem" -> <alias name="S" target="System" kind="namespace" /> "AC TSystem.Console" -> <alias name="C" target="System.Console" kind="type" /> "AS ESystem alias" -> <alias name="S" qualifier="alias" target="System" kind="type" /> "XOldLib" -> <extern alias="OldLib" /> "ZOldLib assembly" -> <externinfo name="OldLib" assembly="assembly" /> "ESystem alias" -> <namespace qualifier="alias" name="System" /> "TSystem.Math" -> <type name="System.Math" />

member.summary: This is how VB Anonymous Types combine hash values for fields. PERF: Do not use with enum types because that involves multiple unnecessary boxing operations. Unfortunately, we can't constrain T to "non-enum", so we'll use a more restrictive constraint.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.FnvOffsetBias
member.summary: The offset bias value used in the FNV-1a algorithm See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function

member.name: F:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.FnvPrime
member.summary: The generative factor used in the FNV-1a algorithm See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.GetFNVHashCode(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Compute the FNV-1a hash of a sequence of bytes See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.GetFNVHashCode(System.Byte*,System.Int32,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Compute the FNV-1a hash of a sequence of bytes and determines if the byte sequence is valid ASCII and hence the hash code matches a char sequence encoding the same text. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function
member.param: The sequence of bytes that are likely to be ASCII text.
True if the sequence contains only characters in the ASCII range.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.GetFNVHashCode(System.Collections.Immutable.ImmutableArray{System.Byte})
member.summary: Compute the FNV-1a hash of a sequence of bytes See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.GetFNVHashCode(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compute the hashcode of a sub-string using FNV-1a See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function Note: FNV-1a was developed and tuned for 8-bit sequences. We're using it here for 16-bit Unicode chars on the understanding that the majority of chars will fit into 8-bits and, therefore, the algorithm will retain its desirable traits for generating hash codes.
member.param: The start index of the first character to hash
The number of characters, beginning with to hash
member.returns: The FNV-1a hash code of the substring beginning at and ending after characters.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.GetFNVHashCode(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compute the hashcode of a sub-string using FNV-1a See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function
member.param: The start index of the first character to hash
member.returns: The FNV-1a hash code of the substring beginning at and ending at the end of the string.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.GetFNVHashCode(System.String)
member.summary: Compute the hashcode of a string using FNV-1a See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.GetFNVHashCode(System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: Compute the hashcode of a string using FNV-1a See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.GetFNVHashCode(System.Char[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compute the hashcode of a sub string using FNV-1a See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function
member.param: The input string as a char array
The start index of the first character to hash
The number of characters, beginning with to hash
member.returns: The FNV-1a hash code of the substring beginning at and ending after characters.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.GetFNVHashCode(System.Char)
member.summary: Compute the hashcode of a single character using the FNV-1a algorithm See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function Note: In general, this isn't any more useful than "char.GetHashCode". However, it may be needed if you need to generate the same hash code as a string or substring with just a single character.
member.returns: The FNV-1a hash code of the character.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.CombineFNVHash(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Combine a string with an existing FNV-1a hash code See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function
member.returns: The result of combining with using the FNV-1a algorithm

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.Hash.CombineFNVHash(System.Int32,System.Char)
member.summary: Combine a char with an existing FNV-1a hash code See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function
member.returns: The result of combining with using the FNV-1a algorithm
